title: Thai culture ministry to propose postponement of national holidays in May to prevent mass gatherings
content:
BANGKOK, April 27 (Xinhua) -- Thailand's ministry of culture on Monday said it will propose to the Cabinet meeting on Tuesday the postponement of holidays on Labor Day (May 1), Coronation Day (May 4), Visakha Puja Day (May 6) and Ploughing Day (May 11).
The ministry said the postponement is necessary to prevent gatherings to avoid another spike in COVID-19 infections.
Following the ministry's proposal, the Centre for COVID-19 Situation Administration (CCSA) also said it will propose to the Cabinet meeting to delay the reopening of department stores, barbers' and hairdressers' shops and restaurants.
"We are in the same position as the Ministry of Culture, reopening of stores and venues will lead to a huge risk in infections," said CCSA spokesman Dr. Taweesin Visanuyothin, "we have come a long way, our COVID-19 curve is on a downward trend. Today (Monday) we had only nine cases. We have come this far and cannot afford to be complacent."
Taweesin also said the National Economic and Social Development Council proposed business resumption but has yet specify any particular business.
Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha on Monday announced the extension of the emergency decree and the six-hour curfew until the end of next month to contain COVID-19 spread.
As head of the CCSA, Prayut told CCSA members to carefully consider the reopening of business matter and its possible impacts. Enditem
